title: WHAT'S THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN AN EXECUTION LIEN AND A ATTACHMENT LIEN?
question: I'M TRYING TO FILE AN ABSTRACT OF JUDGMENT AGAINST JUDGMENT DEBTORS.
answers:
I am enclosing the respective codes of Civil Procedure for your perusal. I recommend you hire an attorney to explain these concepts to you. Thanks for your inquiry. Best of luck.


CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE
SECTION 697.710-697.750

697.710. A levy on property under a writ of execution creates an
execution lien on the property from the time of levy until the
expiration of two years after the date of issuance of the writ unless
the judgment is sooner satisfied.

CODE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE
SECTION 488.500-488.510



488.500. (a) A levy on property under a writ of attachment creates
an attachment lien on the property from the time of levy until the
expiration of the time provided by Section 488.510.
(b) Except as provided in subdivisions (c) and (d), if property
subject to an attachment lien is transferred or encumbered, the
property transferred or encumbered remains subject to the lien after
the transfer or encumbrance to the same extent that the property
would remain subject to an execution lien pursuant to Sections
697.720 to 697.750, inclusive.

Unless the judgment includes either of those two liens (unlikely since you do not even know what they are) you do not check box 10. Just leave it blank. If you have either, it will be specifically mentioned in the judgment.
